abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title>
          <jats:sec>
            <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
            <jats:p>The aim of this study was to determine the genotype distribution and allelic frequencies of <jats:italic>ACE</jats:italic> (I/D), <jats:italic>AGTR1</jats:italic> (A +1166 C), <jats:italic>BDKRB2</jats:italic> (+9/−9) and <jats:italic>LEP</jats:italic> (G–2548A) genomic variations in 175 Greek athletes who excelled at a national and/or international level and 169 healthy Greek adults to identify whether some particular combinations of these loci might serve as predictive markers for superior physical condition.</jats:p>
          </jats:sec>
          <jats:sec>
            <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
            <jats:p>The D/D genotype of the <jats:italic>ACE</jats:italic> gene (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.034) combined with the simultaneous existence of <jats:italic>BDKRB2</jats:italic> (+9/−9) (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.001) or <jats:italic>LEP</jats:italic> (G/A) (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.021) genotypes was the most prevalent among female athletes compared to female controls. A statistical trend was also observed in <jats:italic>BDKRB2</jats:italic> (+9/−9) and <jats:italic>LEP</jats:italic> (G–2548A) heterozygous genotypes among male and female Greek athletes, and in <jats:italic>ACE</jats:italic> (I/D) only in male athletes. Finally, both male and female athletes showed the highest rates in the <jats:italic>AGTR1</jats:italic> (A/A) genotype.</jats:p>
          </jats:sec>
          <jats:sec>
            <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
            <jats:p>Our results suggest that the co-existence of <jats:italic>ACE</jats:italic> (D/D), <jats:italic>BDKRB2</jats:italic> (+9/−9) or <jats:italic>LEP</jats:italic> (G/A) genotypes in female athletes might be correlated with a superior level of physical performance.</jats:p>
          </jats:sec>
publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
